prs.title: op-acceptance: Reduce flakiness of proofs tests
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

Move the proofs withdrawal test to its own package. It time travels L1 a week into the future and the L2s take quite a while to catch up which impacts any tests that run after this one.  It's much more efficient to spin up a dedicated system that it torn down at the end of the test instead of waiting for the L2 to catch up.

Also tweaked the way super root proposals are made s

op-acceptance: Wait for L2 cross safe head to progress before creating game.

Uses the current cross safe timestamp when creating games to avoid needing to wait for safe head to advance.

op-acceptance: Move withdrawal test to own package.

Time travelling L1 a week into the future makes the L2 lag behind for a long time after the test completes. That causes unexpected flakiness.
Ultimately time travel tests need to have a disposable system.

prs.title: refactor: x/btcstaking handles fp ops (backport #1300)
prs.truncated_body:
At the moment, finality provider operations are handled both in the x/btcstaking and x/btcstkconsumer modules. This is not very effective for the following reasons:
* Complex logic: For every finality provider operation, we have to check whether this is a Babylon Genesis fp or a consumer BSN fp and route to the appropriate model.
* Duplicated logic: Many data structures need to be duplicated leadi

commits.message:
refactor: x/btcstaking handles fp ops (#1300)

At the moment, finality provider operations are handled both in the
x/btcstaking and x/btcstkconsumer modules. This is not very effective
for the following reasons:
* Complex logic: For every finality provider operation, we have to check
whether this is a Babylon Genesis fp or a consumer BSN fp and route to
the appropriate model.
* Duplicated logic: Many data structures need to be duplicated leading
to additional stores (3 new stores for fps on the x/btcstkconsumer) or
the reusage of internal module data structures (such as the x/btcstaking
FinalityProvider) across different modules.

To resolve these considerations, this PR transfers all finality provider
logic to the x/btcstaking module, while allowing the x/btcstkconsumer
module handle only consumer BSN registration tracking operations. Below
we outline the major modifications of the PR:

* **Message flow**: x/btcstaking `MsgCreateFinalityProvider` now handles
all finality provider registrations instead of forwarding consumer BSN
ones to the x/btcstkconsumer module. The corresponding fuzz test has
been updated to reflect the full test case.
* **Storage**: the following storage modifications wewre made:
* Removed the `fpPk => bsnId` mapping from the x/btcstkconsumer storage.
* Consumer finality providers are now stored as their Babylon Genesis
peers on x/btcstaking.
* To facilitate "Give me all fps securing a BSN ID" queries (which are
common ones) we introduce a secondary index for fast lookup by BSN ID:
`bsn_id || fp_btc_pk -> nil (just existence marker)`.
* This allows for limited overhead for getting all `fp_btc_pk` for a
`bsn_id` using an index store.
* **Queries**: Moved all x/btcstkconsumer finality provider queries to
x/btcstaking.
* This only required the modification of the `QueryFinalityProviders`
query to now support querying by BSN ID.

This PR also comments out the finality contract e2e test as it fails due
to the interfaces undergoing a major change.

**TODOs** (after the PR is merged):
* **Replace chain ID-based FP type detection**: Instead of using
`fp.BsnId == ctx.ChainID()` to identify Babylon genesis FPs, implement a
more explicit method (e.g., a dedicated field, method like
`fp.IsConsumerFP()`, or constants). Nonetheless we'll need an upgrade
handler. #1306
* **Unify finality provider logic**: Audit and consolidate the scattered
type-specific logic in x/btcstaking (identify specific methods/files
where Babylon vs Consumer FP separation exists and determine if it's
necessary) #1309
* **Expand consumer FP test coverage**: Most of the fuzz tests now work
with Babylon Genesis fps. We can try to expand our test suite to have
more cases that contain a mix of Babylon Genesis and consumer BSN fps.
#1310
* **Update documentation**: The `x/btcstaking` module documentation
should now be updated to reflect the increased responsibilities of the
`x/btcstaking` module. #1307
* **Collections usage**: Examine using a collection for keys as per the
comment
[here](https://github.com/babylonlabs-io/babylon/pull/1300#discussion_r2188791383).
Nonetheless we'll need an upgrade handler for that. #1308

We can create github issues for the above once we are in alignment.

P.S. this is a pretty big change that can lead to lots of conflicts, so
I suggest we prioritize its review. If we agree on this direction, we
can address some of the comments/changes in subsequent smaller PRs.

(cherry picked from commit 798b31d49fa02a8c24b7c27f1355b3dd52a22904)

commits.message:
refactor: x/btcstaking handles fp ops

At the moment, finality provider operations are handled
both in the x/btcstaking and x/btcstkconsumer modules.
This is not very effective for the following reasons:
* Complex logic: For every finality provider operation,
  we have to check whether this is a Babylon Genesis fp
  or a consumer BSN fp and route to the appropriate model.
* Duplicated logic: Many data structures need to be duplicated
  leading to additional stores (3 new stores for
  fps on the x/btcstkconsumer) or the reusage of internal
  module data structures (such as the x/btcstaking FinalityProvider)
  across different modules.

To resolve these considerations, this PR transfers all finality provider
logic to the x/btcstaking module, while allowing the x/btcstkconsumer
module handle only consumer BSN registration tracking operations.
Below we outline the major modifications of the PR:

* **Message flow**: x/btcstaking `MsgCreateFinalityProvider`
  now handles all finality provider registrations instead of forwarding
  consumer BSN ones to the x/btcstkconsumer module. The corresponding
  fuzz test has been updated to reflect the full test case.
* **Storage**: the following storage modifications wewre made:
  * Removed the `fpPk => bsnId` mapping from the x/btcstkconsumer storage.
  * Consumer finality providers are now stored as their Babylon Genesis peers
    on x/btcstaking.
  * To facilitate "Give me all fps securing a BSN ID" queries (which are common ones)
    we introduce a secondary index for fast lookup by BSN ID:
    `bsn_id || fp_btc_pk -> nil (just existence marker)`.
    * This allows for limited overhead for getting all `fp_btc_pk` for a `bsn_id`
      using an index store.
* **Queries**: Moved all x/btcstkconsumer finality provider queries to x/btcstaking.
  * This only required the modification of the `QueryFinalityProviders` query to
    now support querying by BSN ID.

This PR also comments out the finality contract e2e test as it fails due to
the interfaces undergoing a major change.

prs.title: pack: pack is responsible for ending leader slots
prs.truncated_body: In full Firedancer the bank forks objects are implicitly refcounted by the leader pipeline, so they are acquired by pack and released by poh, because of this pack must "flush" the pipeline and give poh a way to guarantee the bank fork is not in use when it releases, which it can do by exactly sequencing the done packing messaage (must arrive after the bank microblocks).

pack: pack is responsible for ending leader slots

In full Firedancer the bank forks objects are implicitly refcounted by
the leader pipeline, so they are acquired by pack and released by poh,
because of this pack must "flush" the pipeline and give poh a way to
guarantee the bank fork is not in use when it releases, which it can do
by exactly sequencing the done packing messaage (must arrive after the
bank microblocks).

prs.title: Replace toEngine channel with a dedicated subscription API
prs.truncated_body:
## Why this should be merged

The API change in this PR is needed to support consensus protocols which facilitate censorship resistance as part of their protocol and therefore need information about whether a block should be built or not on demand, in contrast to the current `toEngine` pattern which notifies the consensus when new transactions arrive only once and is asynchronous to the operat

commits.message:
This commit removes the toEngine channel pattern from all VMs and adds an additional API:

```
SubscribeToEvents(ctx context.Context) Message)
```

Which returns when an event (pending transactions or state sync done Message) is sent by the VM.

Unlike the toEngine pattern which only notifies the consumer a single time until a block is built, successive calls to `SubscribeToEvents` will return that transactions are pending as long as the mem-pool is not empty and a block can be built, otherwise the calls block.

The API change is needed to support consensus protocols which facilitate censorship resistance as part of their protocol and therefore need information about whether a block should be built or not on demand, in contrast to the curren toEngine pattern which notifies the consensus when new transactions arrive only once, and then block building may even fail. Having such an API on the VM side (and not implementing the logic in consensus) forces the VM to handle any side effects of block building (such as re-introducing transactions into the mempool).

prs.title: eth/filters: add address limit to filters (#31876)
prs.truncated_body:
Cherry picks https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/31876:

The address filter was never checked against a maximum limit, which can be somewhat abusive for API nodes. This PR adds a limit similar to topics

This pull request introduces a new validation to enforce a maximum limit on the number of addresses allowed in filter criteria for Ethereum logs. It includes updates to the `FilterAPI

commits.message:
eth/filters: add address limit to filters (#31876)

The address filter was never checked against a maximum limit, which can
be somewhat abusive for API nodes. This PR adds a limit similar to
topics

This pull request introduces a new validation to enforce a maximum limit
on the number of addresses allowed in filter criteria for Ethereum logs.
It includes updates to the `FilterAPI` and `EventSystem` logic, as well
as corresponding test cases to ensure the new constraint is properly
enforced.

* **Validation for maximum addresses in filter criteria**:
- Added a new constant, `maxAddresses`, set to 100, to define the
maximum allowable addresses in a filter.
- Introduced a new error, `errExceedMaxAddresses`, to handle cases where
the number of addresses exceeds the limit.
- Updated the `GetLogs` method in `FilterAPI` to validate the number of
addresses against `maxAddresses`.
- Modified the `UnmarshalJSON` method to return an error if the number
of addresses in the input JSON exceeds `maxAddresses`.
- Added similar validation to the `SubscribeLogs` method in
`EventSystem`.

* **New test cases for address limit validation**:
- Added a test in `TestUnmarshalJSONNewFilterArgs` to verify that
exceeding the maximum number of addresses triggers the
`errExceedMaxAddresses` error.
- Updated `TestInvalidLogFilterCreation` to include a test case for an
invalid filter with more than `maxAddresses` addresses.
- Updated `TestInvalidGetLogsRequest` to test for invalid log requests
with excessive addresses.

These changes ensure that the system enforces a reasonable limit on the
number of addresses in filter criteria, improving robustness and
preventing potential performance issues.

---------

Co-authored-by: zsfelfoldi <zsfelfoldi@gmail.com>

In https://github.com/hiero-ledger/hiero-consensus-node/issues/18458, we changed how we write events into the pces files (we now sync on every event and write using the strongest available guarantee). It produced an increased i/o activity on the disks.
This configuration rolls back the change.

prs.title: Optimize: no escaped string for command line input
prs.truncated_body:
# Description

When using `neo-cli` to input characters that need escaping, sometimes they must be escaped twice, such as a string is a JSON string.

So this PR adds the backticks(\`) to quote strings that don't need to be escaped.
Like:  \` in golang, `""" ... """` in C#.

For example(Escaped twice, from cli input and json):
> '"{\\\\"name\":\\\\"fBNBv2\\\\", // more content..."'

After

commits.message: Optimize: no secaped char for command line input
